pros: The only positive is the team members you will have the pleasure to work alongside. I do believe Amgen has some of the most talented people in their respective fields, but they also have a hard time keeping the smart ones. Those that stay have a callousness quality, which is fed back into the culture negatively.
cons:
Expect to work 12 hours a day or more on the average if you are in any position of responsibility.

a) The organization lacks structure, and support is rarely available to guide the team when it counts.  
b) Management will often de-rail projects within the group by getting involved in the weeds without remediating any of the problems.  
c)Expect to be micromanaged, and if you happen to have any new ideas, the old guard is there to tell you all the reasons why it can’t be done.
d) Management is too busy managing up and does not have time to coach novice team members. I think this is a serious issue that needs to be addressed. 
e) There are at countless hours of team meetings that are often disorganized and waste time. 
f) None of the management knows how to facilitate professional usability studies nor moderate a session. 

That is just the tip of the ice iceberg.  If you are looking for a place to grow your skills, this is not the place.  The real decision-makers are outside consultants 100% of the time.

review_title: Not a good place to work.
pros: Good benefits package.  Good profit sharing plan.

review_title: Adapt and evolve or get weeded out-Study Management

job_title: Principal Programmer Analyst in Thousand Oaks, CA

job_title: Senior Manager in Thousand Oaks, CA
pros: This company is truly going places with a growth strategy that makes sense. The long term success is a given with this momentum of potential blockbuster acquisitions and the pipeline including innovator as well as biosimilar molecules.

job_title: Senior Quality Analyst in Thousand Oaks, CA
pros: Amgen has a very talented workforce that is committed to quality & safety. They offer part cutting edge technologies in their search for life saving therapies. You are constantly learning and growing at Amgen if you are able to stay plugged in.

pros: Amgen is a great place to start off with excellent benefits.  Great resume building company that emphasizes cross functional training and communication.

review_title: Great work like balance & time off,   horrible health insurance in the US
pros: great people, two weeks of US shutdown (July 4th and Christmas) great work life balance, encouraging work environment, managers are interested in your growth and potential, very innovative company they are doing cutting edge things compared to other drug companies and its exciting to be a part of.
cons: Horrible health insurance in the US, I was actually shocked at how bad it was when I joined, its worse than the CRO I came from.. pros: Boulder county is not the biotech hot-spot that Massachusetts or California is and Amgen offers the most generous compensation and benefits packages that I have found in the area. review_title: Good company but poor management at Fremont site

cons:

pros: Good compensation, nice community (Thousand Oaks, Southern California).  Integrated full-service business campus.  Excellent research facilities.
cons:
Incredibly focused on the bottom line, to the detriment of the public health component of the business model.  Extremely willing to sell expensive products, particularly to large number of patients, ~90% of whom may not receive benefit over other treatment choices or even no treatment at all, ~10% who may receive a clinical benefit, but also including some who might not experience benefit but do experience clinically significant adverse events.  Strong supporter of higher dosages until safety profile precludes further dose increase. 

Harsh interpersonal environment driven by need to deliver on progress on goal (sell more drug), without significant consideration of societal needs or benefit, beyond that trickling down from incredibly well-compensated management.   Positions itself as a benefactor of society, but definitely not the company it used to be, by about 6 times over.

review_title: Not for everyone. Great benefits and salary. But is it worth it?

review_title: Great company when you look at all the aspects, uncertain future however.

cons: I don't have any cons. I have been in the industry for 22 years and Amgen is indeed exceptional.

job_title: International Quality Assurance Specialist in Camarillo, CA
pros: Amgen Thousand Oaks is the corporate location which allow several opportunities to explore different fields and organization.  The company is expanding with the launch of several new products and a expanding pipe line.  The benefits include 3 weeks vacation and 2 weeks of shutdown.  Onsite daycare, gym, dry-cleaners and several food places.  Bonus package have been genorous from 12-20%.
cons: The reduction in force from 2015 resulted in a huge loss of expierenced high level employees.  This caused a huge resource drain that left the company with many obstacles.  Staff are asked to fill in the gaps which assuming more work with less resources.  This is taking a toll on the remain employees.

review_title: Amgen management feast richly upon your enthusiasm and achievement.
job_title: Sourcing Guru in Thousand Oaks, CA
pros: Good pay, good bennies.  The campus is nice.  There is a gym and subsidized cafeterias around.  The employees tend to look elegant.
cons:
You manager is not your friend, per unwritten guidelines for
Interpersonal relations.  You walk in the door, astute about the opportunity to improve things.  Your boss will steal your ideas and facemask you and toss you down the stairs.  Director level desperately clings to its privilege and with sociopathic panache will throw you under the bus.  Trust not, become artful in achieving absolutely nothing, and you may advance.

review_title: Opportunities go to upper management, no job security
pros: Beautiful campus, good pay and benefits, great relocation benefits, a young company that tends toward forward thinking
cons: No job security - continual reductions in force and job insecurity.  A lot of positions are being contracted out, I would guess at least 50% of the work force at the Thousand Oaks campus are contracted employees.  Work life balance can be hard to achieve - the more positions lost, the more we are expected to "do more with less", but no assistance or guidance on how to make it happen is given, just an ever increasing work load.Upper management sheds work to direct reports and can often give little guidance/have unrealistic expectations

review_title: Continous Change - Not What Amgen Used To Be
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Thousand Oaks, CA
pros:
Great Benefits: Match 401K, Summer and Winter Shutdown, Stock Options for permanent employees, good health care plans and paid leave of absence
Working in Teams: A pleasure working with the most intelligent, hardworking, and willingness to take risk team members. Best team experience I've had in the industry
cons: The company is shifting to more and more contingent workers and driving out or laying off the experienced workforce. There will be limited career opportunities unless you are critical hire. The workload has increased significantly and prioritization communications are slow in getting to line managers. Moral is poor as workforce waits for next RIF.  Organization is in free fall waiting for new business process to be rolled out across the organization.

review_title: Grass is not greener on the other side
pros: Every division is equal among sales reps. If you work in one division and want to transfer to another, it will be a lateral move. All positions with this company are specialty. The medicine/science with in this company is unbelievable! The company has great stock and plenty of money.
cons: Micro managed and not streamlined evenly throughout the company. Allows some managers to extreme micromanage while others can do whatever they want. There should be better guidance and fluidity with in management within and across every district, region, and specialty. Not the best data either.

review_title: Unfortunate to be part of the decline of a once exciting and important company.
pros: Leaders in implementing new technologies and business strategies. Benefits are very good and they offer a lot of employee programs to support health and family. (Unfortunately, everyone is so over worked they can't benefit from these programs, but at least the company is making them available.)
cons: More time is spent on corporate spin than on actually developing and manufacturing drugs. The politics have overwhelmed the work that is being done. Every bit of data is massaged and presented in presentations and more time is actually spent on colors and charts than on the actual data that went into the reports. So much time is spent "talking" about the data, the message behind the data is actually missing.

review_title: Company has lost its way pandering to wall street.
pros: Some of the brightest people in the scientific community work for Amgen.   You will have to work hard to finding a better compensation package.  It is exceptional.
cons: The number of actual Amgen employees is diminishing with emphasis on outsourcing almost everything.  Many of the best scientists  have left over the last few years.  Management came up with the brilliant idea of closing the Seattle site to save money.  They apparently thought that people would move from Seattle to San Francisco or Boston.  Brilliant move.

review_title: Great Company! But not without some issues.
job_title: Strategic Sourcing Manager in Thousand Oaks, CA
pros: Excellent company.  Smart people.  Great to work for a company that's creating human therapeutics to help improve lives.  Cutting-edge campus.  Great pay / bonus, excellent 401K match.  Christmas week shutdown and 4th of July shutdown time off, in addition to vacation.
cons: Biotech is a volatile industry.  Company constantly changing to remain competitive.   Since joining, I've continually looked over my shoulder with frequent org changes / layoffs.  Non-core business functions (i.e. back office support, etc.), these roles are not always given the priority that's given to the science side, which is understandable.  Can be difficult to find other internal roles, as it can be  challenging to get noticed within such a big organization.

review_title: Amgen has great benefits, but only so-so career opportunities
pros: Terrific benefits and opportunities to learn.  Generous vacation and holiday pay, and great 401K matching.  Mature, successful company with opportunities to learn about biotech/pharma process from beginning to end.
cons: Extremely silo-ed organization.  Can be very difficult to have positive impact on or move a stagnant process or group.  Company tended to discount employees' previous experience and opinions if the experience wasn't at Amgen -- though they like to hire experienced people from outside the company.  Very top-down management style, not collaborative.  Benefits are often referred to as the golden handcuffs.

review_title: A great company, but too top heavy
pros: At the moment, there are plenty of opportunities for staff development.  I'm not sure how much longer that will be available. Work life balance was a priority several years ago.  They have a decent pay scale and the worst bonus I ever had was far better than anything I ever got in Academia
cons: The company is too top heavy- so many VPs.   Right now, the emphasis is bottom line for the shareholders and not so much for the employees.  Communication is not a priority from the top down, and it seems the rumor mill is rife.

job_title: Senior Engineer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Opportunity and advancement is there
cons: Long Hours, long drive, housing expensive

review_title: Stable company with good benefits if you aren't in I.T.
job_title: Systems Administrator in Thousand Oaks, CA
pros: Amgen is a stable company with good benefits.  It's products really do help people, and I can tell that the scientists I have worked are committed and really believe in what they are doing.  The company expects their staff to work hard, and yet does understand the need for work / life balance.
cons: Unfortunately, if you are in I.T., I would think twice before coming to Amgen.  Outsourcing is the theme for 2008 - 2009.  I.S. Infrastructure is underway now, and there will definitely be more to come.  Speedy decisions are a think of the past -- too many layers of management with too few people to actually do the work.

review_title: Amgen has great people and products but needs to grow into it's leadership and management challenges.
job_title: Product Manager in Thousand Oaks, CA
pros: I work on products that are saving lives every day.  My management promotes and supports continuous development on and off the job.  I work with other smart people to solve the some of the most important and challenging problems in our society.
cons: Amgen is a grew from a small biotech into a large company that still has not developed all of the right systems.  Regulatory and human safety requirements impose constraints and create difficulties that are unimaginable in many other industries.  We sell our products in a complex operating environment with new competitors, legal issues, ethical challenges, and risky science.  These operating challenges make the most simple tasks difficult.

review_title: Bright future, but long way to go toward recovery
job_title: Product Manager in Thousand Oaks, CA
pros: Location, location, location!  Thousand Oaks is a great place to live and work.  The schools in Conejo Valley are great, and the weather is tough to beat.  Amgen campus is no longer cramped and crowded and for the most part we have a good work environment.
cons: The company is rebuilding and there is much uncertainty as to how things will look in the near term.  Long term I do believe the company will do very well, but there will be much angst between now and then.  Many great people have left voluntarily or involuntarily in the past year and it is a shame to see a loss of such talent.

pros:
New office and lab spaces
Low stress environment
Average pay but good benefits
cons:
Over the last year something changed. A lot of people (over 6 coworkers) starting leaving which is unsettling because it makes me wonder if I should get out too. When asked about this, management gave a "stop-the-bleeding" PR response.
"Amgen is so good on resumes that our employees are leveraging it to seek jobs in a growing biotech job market"

review_title: What can I say not so good ending...
pros: Great place to work on main campus the grounds are beautiful well kept. Friendly people. Since of pride for the company while there. Lots of learning opportunities
cons: I got laid off, totally blindsided and I feel this was due to poor management of projects and constent turn over.  Working for a big compnay has its cons and Amgen displays all of them. Too many cooks in the kitchen and typical poor business practices.  It is a shame because the company used to be one of the best in the area.

pros: Great products, benefits, salary, bonus
cons: Deceptive Company. All the way to the very end for me. Lied to us about expansion, future ect....Bad culture. From the very beginning I was led to believe this place had a great culture. Wrong! Everyone man from himself at this organization. Co-workers throw each other under the bus and these behaviors are encouraged.  At one time perhaps a great culture has now been destroyed. Never have I seen so many incompetent leaders in my life all the way down to District Sales Managers. Worst I've seen. To this day, not sure how this woman was promoted. Absolutely, the laziest manager I have ever worked for. No benefit of the doubt ever. What goes around comes around.   No accountability here. You could not pay me enough to work at this co again. Stay away unless you are absolutely desperate.  There are much better organizations out there.

job_title: Project Manager in Thousand Oaks, CA
pros: The benefits and compensation packages are good. If you dont mind selling your soul for your company this is the right place for you!
cons: Management is horrible. Work life balance is non-existent.  Not quickly promoted if you are female or over age 40.  They seem to be hiring a lot of "former military" folks in upper mangmnt, which is fine but does not mesh well with the culture of the former Amgen staff (I have been there 12 years).  People are treated differently in the military than in civilian life and they don't make the distinction.  Lots of creepy stuff going on - the rules do not apply the same to all staff members.

review_title: Amgen is a great place to lean the business
job_title: Senior Associate Scientist in Thousand Oaks, CA
pros: Lots of opportunity to learn different areas of biotech and observe leadership styles. Benefits and pay are top notch. The environment is competitive and fast paced.
cons: Lots of changes in 2014 continuing into 2015 so this could affect staff morale. Change is a fact of life though, so if you're willing to work through some tough times, you'll learn a lot from Amgen. With less staff around, the workload will increase but this means opportunity for people willing to do and try new things.

review_title: Was a fun company to work for - not so much anymore. Compensation is great.
pros: Work life balance. Interesting work and good people around you. Good pay in comparison to other biotech companies in area. Great 401k and two week long shutdowns a year.
cons: Layoffs nearly every year. Do more with less. Finance CEO is not inspiring (horrible trickle down effect). In current phase of cost reductions, site closures, layoffs, upper management/HR is pathetic- they've made some embarrassing mistakes and have turned many people away. While stock price has jumped up due in part to cost cutting measures, long term outlook seems grim on account of lack of inspiration and loss of talent.

pros: Location, campus, on site health club, comp package, annual paid shutdowns, quality of employees, impact of products for grievous illnesses; good strategic planning by management, promise of pipeline
cons: High cost of living at headquarters, decision-making concentrated at top (VP+ level) not well delegated, limited opportunity for advancement, increasing sense that Corporate Leadership does not truly value employees, declining employee benefits due to cost savings focus, move to open office environment is distracting; outsourced services do not compare well to insource model regarding quality

pros: Great pay and family focused environment (annual bbq's, family events, etc.).  Young culture also present, definitely an entrepenuereal ambiance present.  Has not converted to large cold big corporate culture yet, but is showing signs of this transition.  Many opportunities for someone proactive who wants to develop other expertise, but this depends on individual ability to reach out to other departments.
cons: Long hours.  Constant access via blackberry, laptop, mobile.  Slowly moving towards large corporate mentality.  Meaning there is a movement towards compartimentalizing each department.  This affects intercompany mobility and is starting to affect individuals from further developing in areas not originally hired for.

review_title: Amgen: The best biotech company in the world
pros:
I love coming to work every day - Amgen is a great place to be.  It's full of really exciting science, and I feel like innovative new ideas and scientific independence are really valued.  This is the best biotech company in the world with which to work - strong science, strong ethics, fun people.  

But on a less high-minded level, I also have to say that the overall compensation package and work-life benefits are far superior to what I know my colleagues get at other companies.  Working for Amgen has its perks.
cons:
Amgen's gotten big but still tries to integrate all of the sites, and so having to videoconference every meeting gets quite cumbersome.  

Too many layers of management too - it can make things a little too hierarchical at times.

review_title: Doing a good job? Tthey'll tell you that you're not. They won't fire you, they'll just humiliate you until you quit.
pros: Good pay. Good benefits. Nice and safe city. Intelligent people all around.Company's mission is motivating (to serve patients). Cafeteria food is great. Nice gym. Laundry service on site (among others).
cons: Poor career development. Poor management. Poor HR organization. Messy, no structure and process in place.  Unfair treatment to employees depending how many people you know, and who you know. Promotions and movements not transparent, often given to those who have good connections. Not merit-based. Performance review cycle send lots of people into therapy because they like to put you down until you have no self-esteem left. No positive reinforcement.

pros: Management is flexible about time off. Compensation is good for all positions. Bonus has maintained 10% of pay for the last ten years. The Amgen Seattle campus is gorgeous, situated on Elliott Bay.  Many good scientists are attracted to work for the company.
cons: Near constant reorganization of departments gives a sense that leadership cannot make clear decisions. Benefits have waned over the last several years. Morale has been in the basement. Recent efforts to restructure have dragged on for nearly a year with no action. Bench scientists and other technical workers are steadily being replaced by contract workers.

review_title: Great company!  Be prepared for long days and good benefits.
pros: Amgen has excellent benefits.   Provided excellent medical benefits and even paid for my undergrad degree.  The pace is fast and exciting.  Be ready to work hard and be compensated well.
cons: Even though I worked there for 14 years, I never really felt appreciated for my dedication and hard work.  When Kevin Shear became our CEO we became numbers instead of names.  It was a hugh culture shock.  Unfortunately, upper management doesn't seem to recognize when departmental managers are only looking out for themselves.  It hurts moral and decreases productivity.

review_title: Frustrating Place to Advance One's Career
job_title: Senior Manager in Thousand Oaks, CA
pros: The company provides employees with great benefits. The headquarters is world class and located in a beautiful setting. Great cafeterias. Nice people. The truth is highly valued.
cons: Poor stock performance, very political culture, few opportunities for advancement, incompetent management, the compensation and promotion system feels gamed. Good people are not recognized. If you are not ex-Navy or ex-Merck, you have a job, not a career. Good luck getting people to listen to your ideas. Many people feel they have never worked so hard for so little praise, advancement and compensation in their careers.

review_title: A good place to do science and make a difference
pros: Amgen's #1 corporate value is "Be Science Based" and I don't think it is just lip-service.  Internal journal lets me publish (peer-reviewed) papers even in the cases when I'm generating proprietary information.  No "head-in-the-sand" attitudes or ignoring of inconvenient data here.
cons:
Like any really big company it can sometimes be easy to lose sight of where your work fits into the larger puzzle.  Also a big company problem: some bureaucracy issues.
I've only gotten positive feedback at performance reviews, and I know I'm not a 100% perfect employee (although I think I'm pretty darn good), so it makes me wonder if the review process is completely candid.

review_title: Marvelous place to grow...until the Amgen acquisition.
job_title: Associate Director in South San Francisco, CA
pros: Many dedicated people.  Some departments retained intact and still functioning well.  Best corporate cafe EVER.
cons: Departures resulting from acquisition seriously affecting morale for everyone.  Many unplanned departures in addition to the RIFs.  Need to improve change management strategy if retention of employees is important to the Onyx subsidiary's long-term strategy.

review_title: Generally solid company, undergoing growing pains
job_title: Senior Associate Business Analyst in Thousand Oaks, CA
pros:
-great benefits (entire economic value seems competitive with market)
-great coworkers (many genuinely strive to live to the values of our culture)
-underlying business is still solid, but faces challenges
cons:

-appetite for risks and making bold decisions seems much lower on the tail of continuous cost-cutting and pressure to perform immediately
-work-life balance may vary depending on role

pros: Amgen pays great and is very focused on staff wellness, development and work/life balance. Once it was a great company to work for and the feeling of collaboration was unmatched. The environment was one that allowed staff to grow and succeed.
cons: Amgen has steadily been outsourcing every possible function within the company and contingent workers are not treated with the same regard as full time employees. Even staff having transitioned to CW positions are suddenly "less than" and Amgen is sure to make sure that CW's are aware of their status. The recent leadership changes have created a cutthroat corporation, focused only on the bottom dollar rather than a company that has a genuine concern for staff.

review_title: Great people, strong future, watch the culture
pros: There are exceptionally talented and smart people working at Amgen.  The people are genuine, interesting, and fun.  The 401k is one of the top in the industry with a generous match of 5% on top of the 5% core contribution which is given prior to any matching.  Also, the training is outstanding which is very helpful with skills and career development.
cons: The company has undergone several reductions in force lately and this is beginning to impact the morale of the company.

review_title: Get the lot out the door no matter what.
pros: Great products and strong pipeline. Great pay and benefits. Good food, nice facilities, bright people (the ones who actually do the hands-on work =30%)
cons: Relentless AML (Puerto Rico) Management resolve to ship product no matter what. If you go there to work make sure you go for a management position (giving orders), not for an individual contributor position (taking orders and doing the hard work). Low morale. Corporate Hypocrisy at its best.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
collaborative culture
beautiful campus and weather
solid compensation

Amgen is in the middle of a big transformational change program.  CEO says we are "right where we need to be" to meet our financial commitments to investors.  Lots of change has already happened--lots still to go.
cons: Pretty isolated from the rest of the industry down in SoCal, which leads to some siloed and pretty antiquated approaches to things.  35-year-old company still feels adolescent for a company its size.  Decision-making remains a struggle with everyone wanting to weigh in on everything and therefore very slow to get anything done.

job_title: MBA Marketing Intern in Thousand Oaks, CA
pros: A very ethical company that tries hard to target grevious illness when developing therapies.  I got a very meaty summer project and full access to everyone at the company.  People were open and friendly and very willing to help out someone with virtually no science background.  Great experience.
cons: It's located in Thousand Oaks, CA.  It is a very data driven company and used to building consensus before moving forward on decisions.  Occasionally there is a bit of information overload and you spend a lot of time vetting all your ideas/projects through other people.

review_title: A place with a lot of potential.
pros: Amgen is a young company with a strong pipeline.  It wants to be more innovative.  One of the last true biotechs out there.
cons:
There really is no ethnic diversity here at Amgen.   Efforts to change and build a sustainable pipeline of diversity is limited if at all.  

In general, succession planning is ambiguous at best.  It is difficult to understand the appropriate path to senior management positions past a Sr. Manager.  To that point, there are several qualified and over qualified employees that are frustrated on this point.

review_title: Work that makes peoples lives better
job_title: Supply Chain Manager in Thousand Oaks, CA
pros: Benefits such as vacation time and 401k match make it the best around.  Mission is to serve patients and improve their lives provides a "True North" for why we are at work each day.
cons: Heavy workload, long hours, and soon no assigned work spaces unless you an executive director or above.  For Directors and below the company will provide a cubby for your things.

pros: Great campus- very strong ATS

I saw a manager belittle and mistreat so many staff members the fallout of employees was happening fast and no one would even say a word- the manager gave my desk to another employee while i was working from home on an approved day- when i returned i was not even given my desk back- someone had taken all my personal belongings and no one even apologized.   CRAZY UNHEALTHY WORK ENVIRONMENT

pros:

review_title: Company has changed due to financial pressures; discovery research drastically downsized.

Too many layers of management slows down key decision making.
Neuroscience Senior management lack appropriate scientific depth and expertise.  Jealously guard their access to key opportunities.  
Senior Managers unwilling to relinquish control of scope and direction of new target discovery work to appropriate scientific leaders to the detriment of the company.

job_title: Senior Executive Assistant in Thousand Oaks, CA
pros: Employee feel valued through competitive compensation and benefits. Very good VPs, Sr. VPs and CEO staff. Next Gen workspace is fun and promotes team culture!
cons: Exceptional leadership at VP level and above however, many of the Directors/Exec Directors are in their roles mostly because of personal connections or who their spouse is and have zero ability to make high level decisions or manage people. Lots of amgen "couples" at director level and this makes for problematic staff relations with their sense of  entitlement and egos.

pros: Company produces excellent drugs and is committed to patient health.

pros:

-Diverse organization with amazingly talented people; Chances of moving into other roles

- loudness is often considered to be smartness

review_title: Amgen Is Good Company For The Right Person
job_title: Senior Programmer Analyst in Seattle, WA

The company provides great benefits in terms of time off, retirement, and flexibility.  The company is fairly innovative in terms of its research and they have excellent lab facilities.
cons: Its easy to become just a cog in a big wheel at this company.  There is also a tendency for projects to get bogged down in lots of process.  If you are not a scientist then your role is likely one more of support so job duties may not be as exciting or challenging than positions in other companies.

review_title: Competitive pay, but not a long term career option for most.
pros: Very competitive compensation packages.  Nice facilities.
cons: Poor leadership from the top on down.  Relied too much on a few Blockbusters now nearing Patent expiry, current pipeline prospects overstated. Too much uncertainty going forward.  Unclear vision. Too many projects Dead in the Water allowed to go forward with costly Staff.  Undermanned.  Limited advancement opportunities - who you know more important than what you know.

review_title: Ok.... but do not expect a long term job.

It seemed like there was a lot of competition between sites instead of collaboration.  As with any large company, there is a little bit of complacency.

review_title: Once a great place ...  now depressing.

job_title: Senior Manager in Thousand Oaks, CA
pros: Awesome potential, wonderful campus.

review_title: A good start, but losing ground fast.
pros: Healthcare options are good.  Compensation and welcome packages attracktive if salary/position is over 100K.  A group of heroes from different areas effectivelly run the company while others do not lift their own weight.  A powerful and thorough evaluation system with 360 feedback, not used properly and wasted.

review_title: Nice Place, Needs a Little Work to be Great
pros: Focus on mission to serve patients and ethics is admirable. Opportunity to work with some of the brightest minds in the industry is exciting and motivating. cons: Bureaucratic, outsourced finance systems make getting anything done that has to do with payments or using external vendors nearly impossible. Things that should take a few minutes take hours due to complicated, user-unfriendly systems.

job_title: Senior Global Category Manager in Thousand Oaks, CA
pros: Prestigious company; reputation. Exciting place to work surrounded by the some of the brightest and best. Super campus with extensive facilities and a lovely location. Feels good to be working in biotechnology. Future proof industry with good margins and very competitive pay and benefits.
cons: Very aggressive work environment. Hyper-results orientated. High stress, high politics; Machiavellian work colleagues. Lots of processes and procedures but you are only successful if you are master in the dark arts.

review_title: Don’t waste years in a dead end career
pros: Nice cafeteria. Great looking campus. Some amenities.
cons: Many leaders brought in from outside with little experience that make their own decisions based on little fact.  All voices are not heard.  No direction for career growth though they will tell you in the beginning the sky is the limit. Lower levels are made to be Labor machines to churn and burn.

review_title: The company will drain your ability to have a healthy life outside of it.  Hours are long, demands high, progress is slo
pros:
Benefits - they are great
Pay - pretty good compaired to industry

review_title: Didn't seem to have a clear direction of where they were going day-to-day or year-to-year
pros: The benefits were OK, nice newer facilities, they did lots of employee feedback gathering

review_title: Amgen pays well and helps develop its high performers, but it tolerates its low performers indefinitely
job_title: Compliance Senior Manager in Thousand Oaks, CA
pros: Amgen allows a lot of flexibility with your work schedule. People who work there are fairly laid back, so it can be a pretty fun place to work.  The pay and bonuses are great, to say the least.  Everyone down the Admin Coordinator receives a yearly bonus roughly 10-30% of the annual salary, with Directors (maybe EDs) making much more than that (in the range of 70-130% in BONUS on top of their already competitive salaries.
cons: As nice as it is to work somewhere fun, the "fun" factor seems to get in the way of actually getting work done, which I personally find really annoying. For example, if you tell an employee that she hasn't performed her task, it is not uncommon that the employee may cry then take you to HR for being insensitive. review_title: Proud to be an Amgen employee

job_title: Super TechnoNerd in Thousand Oaks, CA
pros: Generous overall compensation, makes important products that address grievous illnesses, severance packages are generous, nice campus with on-site restaurants and gym
cons:
This is public knowledge: like a number of big bio/pharma companies, Amgen is facing patent expiration on many of its biggest money-makers over the next 2-3 years, cutting income by some 40% with nothing in the product pipeline to replace those products in time...there are going to be some years where the company can't make ends meet.  So Amgen is enacting a series of significant layoffs to reduce costs to a similar degree. And that's just what I can tell you based on publicly-available information. Amgen does these layoffs in chunks so they don't make the news, because they treasure their "employer of choice" image. 
 
Day-to-day operations...and more importantly, the annual and semi-annual review process...are controlled by HR. Meaning HR tells the manager what to write in the review, and if the manager balks, HR makes it clear the manager's own position is at risk if they do not comply. 

The company leadership points to a "social architecture" component called the "Amgen Values". These are traits identifying how to behave like a good person while getting work done. But senior management itself does not demonstrate these values. Starting with some Directors, then the majority of Executive Directors, and the entirety of VPs and above, they lie, bully, fight, and put underlings "under the bus" to avoid having their own career damaged.

The company HQ in Thousand Oaks is geographically isolated, 50 miles outside Los Angeles. There are no other major employers in the area. If you move your family out here, and things don't work out, you may find yourself pulling up stakes and moving again.

The company's management structure can only be described as turbulent. Hardly any executive has the job they had two years prior.

The CIO has been in the company for some time but in the CIO role for less than two years. She does not demonstrate an understanding of how I.T. works, and shows no technical skills whatsoever, not even earlier in her career. The "big I.T. achievement" she showed off for 2012 wasn't even developed by I.T., and when handed over to I.T. for operational support, became a maintenance nightmare due to its poor design. She has not produced a single strategy or plan to improve actual I.T. capabilities in alignment with business goals. 

Finally, her radical re-shuffling of personnel...she has replaced her entire direct-report leadership team in less than two years...reveals the traits she hires for most. If you're female and run or bike in the mountains, you have a career waiting for you at Amgen.

As long as I have known Amgen, I remember it to be a biotechnology pioneer, translating efforts in the lab into safe and effective medicines for patients. It really does have one of the deepest pipelines of any biotechnology or pharmaceutical company out there.

Amgen's innovative spirit is still alive and thriving. We are truly on the cutting edge of biotechnology, and there are many exciting discoveries. Amgen therapeutics have changed the practice of medicine, most recently seen with the promise of Denosumab. More than 15 million patients worldwide have been treated with Amgen products and it is motivating to know that you work at a company that makes a real difference in the world.
cons:
As Amgen gets larger, it needs to work even harder for it to maintain the 'old biotech style'. It grew too fast from 2001-2006 and realized in the last couple years that more people do not directly translate to greater success. However, it must make smart investments in the long term. Denosumab is the direct result of major discoveries in bone biology made by Amgen scientists 15 years ago. 

Amgen provides a scientific career path which is very competitive and provides real opportunities for career growth. However, compensation is not always on par with peers in areas outside research and development. Greater incentives will continue to keep the best scientists at Amgen.

Budgeting is penny wise and dollar foolish, with current financial processes that are so bureaucratic and antiquated as to be tangible business risk.
